importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The FAA imposed a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing's 737 MAX in January 2024, following a safety incident involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9.
The FAA officially lifted the production cap on Boeing's 737 MAX, allowing increased output to 42 planes per month as of October 17, 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 38-plane-per-month cap was in place from January 2024, marking a period of strict oversight due to safety concerns.
The lifting of the cap on October 17, 2025, signals a turning point in Boeing's recovery and production capabilities.

keyTakeAways: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has lifted a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing's 737 MAX, allowing production to increase to 42 planes per month.
The cap was originally imposed in January 2024 after a 2024 mid-air emergency involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 that was missing four key bolts.
The FAA conducted extensive safety reviews of Boeing’s production lines to ensure that the increased production rate would be carried out safely.
Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg was contacted by FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford to confirm the production increase, indicating a high level of inter-agency coordination.
Boeing plans to begin producing 42 planes per month immediately, signaling a significant recovery step after years of safety and public trust issues.

namedEntities.name: Boeing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major U.S. aerospace and defense company that designs and manufactures commercial airplanes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boeing is the central subject of the article, as it is directly involved in the production of the 737 MAX aircraft and the recent increase in production capacity.

namedEntities.name: Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. government agency responsible for regulating aviation safety and air traffic.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The FAA imposed and later lifted the production cap on Boeing's 737 MAX, highlighting its regulatory role in ensuring aviation safety.

namedEntities.name: Kelly Ortberg
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The CEO of Boeing, responsible for leading the company’s strategic and operational direction.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was directly involved in the communication with the FAA regarding the production increase, illustrating leadership engagement in safety and recovery efforts.

namedEntities.name: Bryan Bedford
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Administrator of the FAA, responsible for overseeing the agency’s operations and safety standards.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He initiated communication with Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg to confirm the lifting of the production cap, showing direct regulatory oversight and cooperation.

namedEntities.name: Alaska Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major U.S. airline that operates flights using Boeing 737 MAX aircraft.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The incident involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 in 2024 triggered the FAA’s production cap, linking airline operations to regulatory decisions.

namedEntities.name: 737 MAX
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A model of commercial airplane manufactured by Boeing, which faced a major safety crisis following two fatal crashes in 2018–2019.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 737 MAX is central to the article, as the production cap and subsequent increase are tied to safety concerns and recovery efforts.

namedEntities.name: 737 MAX 9
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A specific variant of the 737 MAX aircraft, introduced in 2024, which was involved in a mid-air emergency.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The incident with the 737 MAX 9 directly led to the FAA imposing the production cap, making it a critical event in the timeline.

namedEntities.name: 42 planes per month
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The new production target for Boeing's 737 MAX after the cap was lifted.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This increase marks a significant shift in Boeing’s production strategy and reflects confidence in improved safety and quality control.

namedEntities.name: 38 planes per month
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The previous production cap imposed by the FAA on the 737 MAX.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The prior cap symbolized a period of restricted production due to safety concerns and was a key benchmark before the increase.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has lifted a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing’s 737 MAX, allowing the company to increase output to 42 planes per month. This decision follows a 2024 mid-air emergency involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 that was missing four key bolts, which prompted the initial cap. The FAA conducted extensive safety reviews of Boeing’s production lines to ensure the increase can be implemented safely. Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg was personally contacted by FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford to confirm the change, underscoring collaboration between the company and regulators. The increase signifies a major step in Boeing’s recovery after years of safety scrutiny and public distrust, with both Boeing and the FAA emphasizing that safety and quality remain central to the new production plan.
title: Boeing can hike 737 MAX production to 42 planes per month, FAA says
